content: Added "loop N write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

I downgraded the difficulty to Medium.
If you just follow the statement, it's not hard.

You wrote "Ys = L * (Xc - X ) - Yc (mod P) (eq3)"
I'm guessing X should be Xd?
Seems cool, but as I am not able to do it i'll let more experimented players validate it for you. Good luck.
i took too long to read the description by itself

Not solved yet, however instead of explaining the well-known fast exponentiation method (here used for multiplication) in a "hard" problem (solvers can safely be assumed to know that), you could definitely give more information about the (+) group law https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic_curve#The_group_law (instead of only referring to external resources, all the more as that's required to solve the puzzle).
You should write all the k integers as integers either in decimal or in hexadecimal.

Hello,
I'm posting this proposition of puzzle but I'm not sure that all languages are able to handle an integer > 64bits. If required I may update the puzzle.

Is there a way to write Latex Equation to improve the statement ?

Thnaks by advance for your feedbacks !

To my knowledge, the real issue is JavaScript which only "supports" 53-bits integers.

Moreover, several languages (including C, C++, PHP and OCaml) have being installed without their support for arbitrary large integers. Therefore, I recommend if possible to update your puzzle so that only 62-bits integers are required (from some reason, OCaml is limited to 62 bits).
Oops, I forgot to update the first ones. I'll do that ! Thanks :)

Thanks for your feedback ! For me the fast exponentiation method was the bottleneck to understand it ECC. I never heard about it and I was not expecting this method to be known except for people interested in Cryptography. That's why I explained it. The rest was purely math (quite simple) and as there is no Latex (right ?), I prefered to refer it to sources clearer but I'll update that.
It took you no time at all to come up with this excuse to justify your attempt to earn 15 more XP.
X should be Xs, corrected, thanks.

I did a lot of rewriting, if you have any comments.
Previous version backup https://framabin.org/p/?3ed3d7959a1eaab3#W02hkO4cggHuUi8YsB9AOtfvjchVtlaIwo69/X6fPrM=

I think you added the "Special case: If one term is (0,0), the result is the other one." sentence to the original statement.

I did not remove it for now, but I don't think it makes any sense: (0,0) is not the neutral for the law (technically the neutral is a point at infinity, it's not mentioned here as it should not be needed to solve the problem), moreover (0,0) is not even on the secp256k1 curve.
(In your code, you needed a special case for (0,0) just because you arbitrarily decided to initialize your variables at (0,0).)
I added it because of the special cases that were not clear. You can remove it if you want.
Ok! I removed it, hopefully everything is clear enough now.
Moreover, it take not so long to check that THIS IS NOT A CLASH but an HARD PUZZLE that is the time took to read the statement has no meaning here.
You gain 15 xp by approving / rejecting ? is it permanent ?
Ask yourself why so many not even reviewed contributions are accepted, use the force and the answer you will find

@Trolldejo You only gain 15 XP once the puzzle is accepted/rejected if you have voted towards the final decision.

I don't know if that's an explanation for Master_Zain's vote here as 15 XP is nothing at lvl 20. However, there already is a maximum size for statements and consequently the "too long" argument is not valid as long as the space is properly used to explain the puzzle.
@Master_Zain not going to say something? It's a really good HARD puzzle so rereject it please.
updated :)
Am I stupid or right now G is not even on the curve??!
You are right, I don't know how I compute this new number but I guess I simply applied a square root which should not be the case. I'm trying to fix that asap

Edited (P and GY in "Constrains" and all tests). Nice catch BTW :D
Just FYI, I had to change P as it was not prime and the algo to compute the modular sqrt required it (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonelli%E2%80%93Shanks_algorithm)

Well actually you replaced P = 0x3fddbf07bb3bc557, which was already prime ;-) , by 0x3fddbf07bb3bc551, which is indeed also prime.

Edit: Also (I feel stupid each time I say that :-) ) with the current data (P=0x3fddbf07bb3bc551, GX=0x69d463ce83b758e, GY=0x2cf6c46e659cdce4) G still isn't on the curve!

Edit 2: You meant GY = 0x1763acfeb743d5f5 maybe?

I should feel stupid, because I just checked this and I ended up with a wrong value -_-'. It's updated again (and I've added the check in the solution :D). Maybe on a version 2, I could provide the P, GX, GY for each test case and add an output when the point doesn't belong to the curve... For the P, I don't know if it was not a carmichael number because it didn't passed the test for Tonelli's algo

Ok it's all good (at least for the maths) this time (my GY would also have worked, they both have the same square mod P)!
As for the other P, modular sqrt does not always exist (e.g. 2 is not a square mod 3), I guess that's what was failing with the previous prime.

I didn't saw you Edit 2 (I was probably already looking for the correct one). The test which fails was : pow(GY, (P - 1) // 2, P) != 1 (seems to be Legendre's symbol but I'll have to dig into such math sooner or later :)).
In this exercice, having the point not on the curve would not impact anything (except the outcome). I think it will create an issue only for the encryption/decryption stage (this Key computation is only a part of the Diffie-Hellman Key exchange protocol, maybe maths would be broken with a wrong starting point... but this is out of my knowledge for now).

If the points are not on the curve, then you don't have a group law at all and you cannot make consistent calculations with it much further. As for the new GY, your value simply is the opposite of mine and it actually couldn't be otherwise as, when P is prime (i.e. in a field) the (polynomial) equation x^2 = c mod P has at most 2 solutions (so if you know one non-zero solution, the opposite is the obvious other solution). Furthermore (and coincidentally), as opposite y values <=> opposite in the curve group, and as the puzzle only asks for x values, they both lead to the exact same results. Also, your __mul__() starts by taking n % self.curve.p which makes no sense as the order of G is not P. It does not matter as anyway n

You are right about the group law but let say for this exercice, the main exercice is more or less to implement the fast exponentiation on an elliptical curve (there is also a trap with the modular power which could slow down your code if you apply the "normal one"). Having the point out of the curve will lead to wrong points calculation but that's it (for here).

For the second point, it seems that xÂ² = k mod P has only 2 points only if P is Prime (which is the case here) and yes they are opposites.

for the __mul__(), there is a modulo because you can multiply it more than P times but I think it makes no sense (I'll have a try with a very small P). You may end up at the same point maybe ?

Question : How did you get all that knowledge about number theory :) ?

For your first point, the formulas are derived from a proper geometrical operation (in an abstract algebraic context, but still) assuming the points are on the curve. Applied to points that are not on the curve, these formulas make no sense. Hence for the problem to be solvable when G is not on the curve, you would have to prove that these formulas are still symmetric and associative "enough" so that, regardless of the order in which you do the operations, you get the same result. I've absolutely not thought about it, yet this does not look completely obvious. Right?

For the third point, the iterations of G indeed form a cycle, the right modulo to use is the size of this cycle, which is the number I gave in my previous post.

For the number theory knowledge: a bit of math/theoretical studies, a bit of Project Euler and a bit of personal taste I guess.

I have a suggestion for the "next puzzle": basically simply a reverse puzzle of this one (given kG, find k, by an attack on the discrete log, e.g. baby-step giant-step or Pollard's rho probabilistic attack, or anything else).

Finally I will validate if you take into account my remarks (replace the points P/Q by A/B and say something about the 0 element and the case Xp=Xq, otherwise this will end up with complains on the forum from people who can't solve the problem relying on the statement only).

Thanks for your feedback. I didn't get that you got a problem with the naming of points previously and didn't get also that P is used for the order of G (I followed Wikipedia names).

During the update, the text was too long so I had to adjust it as much as possible to fit in term of characters limit. I replaced P/Q as C/D instead of A/B because they are used for the coefficient of the curve (in Constrains Section).

The specific cases Xc = Xd are also added ( I hope it's understandable :) ).

I'll have a look at you next puzzle proposal. I only heard about discrete log but haven't looked at it in details.
Ok! I fixed a few typos and wording problems before validating.
Thanks ! :)
It's fixed :)
63 bits for ocaml
minus 1 since we need unsigned arithmetic here. That makes 62. ;)
ooops. You're right :rage:
I'm starting to review if it's still valid by only changing the modulo P, the starting point and the K maximum. I have no idea if it's still valid.

Updated (reduced to 62bits). To keep a bit of challenges on the last ones, I increased to 50 examples but the time to compute them are a lot faster and reduce a bit the need of optimization (around 50ms on my computer). It should be still valid for encryption but not safe.
